former_faculty.research_summary:
Our research spans reproductive immunology, cytokine signaling in pregnancy, anti-viral therapeutics, and antibody engineering, with a strong translational focus on vaccine development, therapeutic interventions, and host-pathogen interactions.

1. Zona Pellucida Glycoproteins in Fertilization and Immunocontraception
   We investigate the role of human zona pellucida (ZP) glycoproteins—ZP1, ZP3, and ZP4—in sperm binding and acrosome reaction induction during fertilization. Our findings highlight:

N-linked glycosylation, not O-linked, as crucial for acrosome reaction in humans.

The C-terminal region of ZP3 as its functional domain.

Involvement of Gi-protein-coupled receptors, T- and L-type voltage-operated calcium channels, and various kinases in mediating ZP-induced acrosome reaction.

Building on this mechanistic understanding, we have explored the use of ZP glycoproteins as immunocontraceptive vaccine candidates, demonstrating reduced conception rates in non-human primates. This approach is now being extended to wildlife population management, particularly for street dog control. We have successfully developed a protocol for His-tag-free purification of recombinant canine ZP3 using batch-fed E. coli fermentor systems.

2. Cytokine-Mediated Regulation of Trophoblast Function
   Proper trophoblast proliferation, invasion, and differentiation are vital for placental development and pregnancy success. Our studies focus on the role of the IL-6 cytokine family (IL-6, IL-11, and LIF) in regulating trophoblast behavior:

IL-11 and IL-6 enhance invasion via STAT3 Tyr705 activation.

LIF promotes both invasion and proliferation, additionally activating the ERK1/2 pathway.

Silencing STAT3 reduces IL-11-induced invasion, whereas ERK1/2 is essential for LIF-mediated proliferation.

Through cDNA microarray, we identified MMP23B and pappalysin-1 as critical effectors in cytokine-induced trophoblast invasiveness. Our results suggest IL-11 differentially regulates invasion during early and late pregnancy stages. This work provides mechanistic insight into implantation and may inform novel strategies for managing pregnancy complications.

3. Plant-Derived Anti-HIV Compounds and Microbicide Development
   We are exploring natural compounds from medicinal plants for use in HIV prevention via topical microbicides. Screening of ~30 plant species identified four extracts with potent in vitro anti-HIV activity, targeting:

Reverse transcriptase

Protease

Integrase enzymes

Additionally, synthetic derivatives of andrographolide and integric acid were evaluated. Several andrographolide analogs demonstrated high therapeutic indices (TI > 500), with potent inhibition of viral entry by binding the V3 loop region of HIV-1 gp120. These findings support the development of plant-based or semi-synthetic microbicides for sexual transmission prevention.

4. Antibody Engineering for Influenza Virus Therapeutics
   We aim to develop heterosubtypic monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) for passive immunotherapy against influenza virus infections. Key accomplishments include:

Generation of 49 MAbs targeting pandemic and seasonal H1N1 strains

Identification and humanization of a high-affinity MAb (KD = 2.1 ± 0.4 pM) that neutralizes 2009 pandemic H1N1 (IC₅₀ = 0.08 µg/ml), binding the ‘Sa’ epitope on hemagglutinin (HA)

Isolation of single-chain variable fragments (ScFv) from a human phage display antibody library, specific to both pandemic and seasonal strains

These antibodies offer a promising avenue for therapeutic intervention during severe or emerging influenza outbreaks.

former_faculty.research_interest:
My primary research interests are in understanding the regulation of intracellular trafficking in different cell types which are broadly divided into:
To determine the molecular mechanisms of how intracellular pathogens modulate their trafficking pathways in host cells.
Understanding the regulation of intracellur trafficking pathways in

former_faculty.research_summary:
The scientific contributions of my research are primarily in the area of cell biology with special emphasis on the regulation of intracellular trafficking. We have addressed fundamental issues in host pathogens interactions with an aim to develop a potentially new therapeutic target for their intervention. Our work has provided important insights into the molecular mechanisms of how intracellular pathogens modulate intracellular trafficking pathways to survive in phagocytes. We have demonstrated using an elegant in vitro reconstitution of transport assay that live Salmonella produce a protein, SopE, that helps recruit Rab5 and NSF on the phagosomes containing live bacteria. This promotes fusion of live Salmonella -containing phagosomes with early endosomes so that lysosomal targeting of such phagosomes is avoided. Thus, it is emerging from these studies that SopE could be a new and specific target for selective elimination of Salmonella from the host cells either by blocking the interaction of SopE with Rab5 or by modulating the content of endocytic GTPases in the host cells to divert trafficking of Salmonella to the lysosomes. Finally, we have tested these hypothesis and shown that it is possible to divert Salmonella to the lysosomes for selective killing by modulating the content of endocytic GTPases in the host cells. Interestingly, we have also shown how Salmonella recruits Lysosome Associated Membrane Protein (LAMP1) by fusing with Golgi derieved LAMP1-containing vesicle through the interaction  of their effector molecule, SipC with host Syntaxin6. This is first evidence how an intracellular pathogen recruits LAMP without their targeting to the lysosomes.

Our discovery of a new receptor system mediating uptake and intracellular degradation of hemoglobin by Leishmania suggests how, lacking heme biosynthetic ability, this parasite might meet the requirement of heme essential for its growth. Interestingly, further characterization of the receptor demonstrated that hemoglobin receptor in Leishmania is a suface localized hexokinase, a well characterized glycolytic enzyme. Recently, we have characterized the intercellular route of hemoglobin and their regulation in the parasites by different Rab GTPases by some elegant novel experiments. Our studies have revealed that signaling from the cytoplasmic tail of the hemoglobin receptor targets the hemoglobin to late degradative compartment suggesting that parasites has devised an unique procedure to target the internalized hemoglobin for degradation in late compartment to generate intracellular heme, essentially required by the parasites for growth. Discovery of this new receptor system  for acquiring heme by Leishmania is significant not only as a notable contribution to biology of this group of intracellular parasites but also as a potential new target against these parasites of paramount public health importance in the developing countries.

Survival of intracellular pathogens in the host cells depends on the balance between pro-inflammatory and anti-inflammatory cytokines suggesting that these cytokines possibly modulate distinct steps in the endocytic pathway and thereby regulate phagosome maturation. However, how cytokine modulate intracellular trafficking is not yet known. We have identified a novel mechanism of cytokine mediated modulation of the expression of Rab GTPase. We have shown that treatment of macrophages with IL-6 specifically induce the expression of Rab5 through the activation of extracellular signal-regulated kinase, whereas IL-12 exclusively unregulate the expression of Rab7 through the activation of p38 MAPK.  Finally, we have shown that IL-12 mediated overexpression of  Rab7 induces lysosomal transport whereas IL-6 stimulates the fusion between early compartments in macrophages and accordingly modulate trafficking and survival of intracellular pathogens in macrophages. This is the first demonstration showing that the existence of a unique regulation of membrane trafficking directly dependent on different cytokines.
We have also made seminal contributions to establish for the first time the feasibility of receptor-mediated enodocytosis as an alternative approach to deliver various drugs to macrophages using exquisite specificity and high efficiency process of scavenger receptor mediated endocytosis. We have shown that scavenger receptor-mediated intracellular delivery of various drugs to macrophages combat various infections as well as cancer cells both in vitro and in vivo .

former_faculty.research_interest:
Our laboratory is engaged in researches at the interface of chemistry and biology. We are interested in developing chemoenzymatic strategies for semisynthesis of proteins and bio-conjugates by combining enzymatic peptide ligation with chemical peptide synthesis, organic synthesis and recombinant protein expression.
Key words:
Chemical biology, Synthetic protein chemistry, Peptide ligation, Protein engineering, Sortase
former_faculty.research_summary:
In the past we have addressed mechanistic aspects of peptide ligation reactions catalyzed by proteases. We have elaborated the concept of product-specific traps as a mechanism to facilitate reverse proteolytic condensation of polypeptide fragments. Furthermore, we have established volume exclusion effect, emanating from macromolecular crowding or confinement, as a driving force for reverse proteolysis.
Current work in our laboratory is focused on elucidating the amide bond forming specificity of bacterial transpeptidase (referred to as sortases). Sortases are cysteine transpeptidases that anchor surface proteins to the cell wall in Gram-positive bacteria. The archetypal sortase (SrtA) of Staphylococcus aureus recognizes a pentapeptide LPXTG motif present near the carboxy terminus of surface proteins, cleaves the T-G peptide bond and ligates the Protein-LPXT to the aminoglycine of the pentaglycine sequence present in peptidoglycan leading to anchoring of proteins to the cell wall.
SrtA-mediated peptide ligation reaction also proceeds well with short LPXTG peptides and aminoglycine terminated sequences. The propensity of SrtA to recognize short consensus sequences has inspired the use of this enzyme as a versatile synthetic tool in protein chemistry and chemical biology. Several applications of SrtA including introduction of novel functionality (viz., fluorescent labels, lipids, GPI anchors etc) into proteins, generation of circular proteins and surface immobilization of proteins have emerged in the past 7-8 years.  Contemporaneously, we have been engaged in exploring the utility of SrtA in the synthesis of glycoconjugates, cyclic peptides, branched peptide oligomers and multivalent protein dendrimers that are not amenable to synthesis by purely chemical or genetic means.

former_faculty.name: Dr. Lalit C. Garg
former_faculty.research_interest: Infectious diseases are the leading causes of death of both humans and animals. Vaccination is one of the most effective methods to control many infectious diseases. The primary focus of my laboratory is to unravel the molecular mechanisms of infectious diseases to explore new drug targets and development of vaccines against pathogens.
former_faculty.research_summary:
Gram positive Clostridium perfringens is a major cause of human and veterinary enteric disease largely because this bacterium can produce several toxins when present inside the gastrointestinal tract. Epsilon toxin, produced by Clostridium perfringens types B and D is the key antigen implicated in the Enterotoxaemia or Pulpy kidney disease of domestic animals. It is the third most lethal of all clostridial toxins. Epsilon toxin functions by interacting with the surface of mammalian cells probably through receptor binding and oligomerizes to form pores. Our initial focus is to identify the residues important for receptor binding as well as residues involved in oligomerization. We envisage to isolate the receptor for epsilon toxin to understand this interaction in greater detail. Further, by site-directed mutagenesis we aim to study the role of various residues within the gene for its toxicity and immunogenicity. Another emphasis of our research is to develop recombinant protein and DNA based vaccines against C. perfringens , C. novyi, C. chauvoei and D. nodosus.

My laboratory is also interested in Mycobacterium tuberculosis . More than 2.5 million deaths every year make tuberculosis one of the most lethal infectious diseases. Recent years have seen an increase in incidence of tuberculosis in both developing and industrialized countries, and there is an immediate need to search for new molecules that can be used as future drug target(s). In vivo growth studies of the organism have indicated that up to 70% of glucose metabolizes through the EMP pathway. Thus, glycolysis is central to the organism's survival and targeting the glycolytic enzymes, as potential drug targets to control M. tuberculosis may be feasible. My laboratory envisages cloning and expressing the genes of metabolic pathways beginning with the enzymes of EMP pathway. Subsequently genes encoding the enzymes of other metabolic pathways will be evaluated. Biochemical characterization of the recombinant enzymes will help in identifying the differences and similarities between the Mtb and human, which can be exploited for drug development. Further, production of large amounts of recombinant protein using efficient expression strategies would make it possible to carry out structural studies. This will help in defining the 3-dimensional structure of the enzymes ultimately leading to the rational development of new therapeutic interventions.

Sequencing of the complete genome of M. tuberculosis H37Rv has revealed that approximately 8% of the total genome codes for members of two large families of conserved proteins, the PE and PPE families. The uniqueness of the genes of the PE and PPE families is that these are specifically present in mycobacteria and are mainly restricted to the pathogenic strain. Despite their numerical abundance and interesting distinctiveness, function of these genes remains largely unknown. A true understanding of the gene products  of a pathogen is essential for the successful control of disease. Functional characterization and defining the role of this unique family of proteins in mycobacterium biology may provide novel targets for chemotherapeutic intervention of tuberculosis.

former_faculty.research_interest: Macromolecular structure and dynamics (Key words: NMR, Protein Folding)
former_faculty.research_summary: Our laboratory is interested in elucidating the gamut of structural elements in a protein which control its function. For example glycolytic enzymes from parasitic protozoa are significantly different from mammalian homologues in their cellular role and regulation. The tertiary structures of Phosphoglycerate kinase from different organisms are very similar even though in some cases the sequence homology is no more than fifty percent.  How can one then account for differences in substrate binding and catalysis? Proteins are not rigid balls but dynamic molecules that can bend, slide and reorient themselves.  B-factor of residues in crystallographic structures as well as the rmsd of backbone and side-chains in solution structures are indicators of strong dynamic regions in a biomolecule. NMR methodology can be used effectively to look at protein microenvironments under different solution conditions. In principle movements on medium to slow scale can be trapped and studied by NMR.  These lead to important clues to protein function.

former_faculty.research_summary:
We been investigating the role of human ribonucleases, including human pancreatic ribonuclease (HPR), EDN and ECP in host defense. HPR has a unique property of having a strong double stranded RNA cleavage activity. We have demonstrated that for the double stranded RNA cleavage activity of HPR glycine 38 is very important, and the basicity of the protein also plays a crucial role. In a very significant study we have shown that the interaction between HPR and ribonuclease inhibitor (RI) can be disrupted by mutating residues involved in HPR-RI binding. The inhibitor-resistant HPR mutants have been shown to manifest cytotoxic activity towards tumor cells. Further, using an inhibitor-resistant HPR mutant a recombinant dimeric HPR variant has been generated which shows specific cytotoxicity to tumor cells. The catalytic mechanism of eosinophil ribonuclease, EDN has also been delineated by our group to understand its role in eosinophil biology. We have also delineated the mechanism of antibacterial activity of ECP, and antiviral activity of EDN.
To understand the mechanism of action of a potent ribonucleolytic protein toxin, restrictocin from Aspergillus , we have identified a crucial histidine residue responsible for the target recognition, delineated the role of various cysteines and prolines in restrictocin catalysis, and also defined the functional boundaries in the toxin molecule. We have also solved the mechanism of specific target recognition and RNA hydrolysis by ribonucleolytic toxin restrictocin by an extensive mutational analysis and molecular modeling.
Aspergillus
The knowledge generated by the structure-function investigations was used to develop and engineer restrictocin based recombinant immunotoxins for targeted therapy of cancer. A strategy was developed to enhance the intracellular processing of restrictocin containing immunotoxins by incorporating a proteolytically cleavable spacer in these molecules. It is now possible to use ribonucleolytic toxin restrictocin to construct immunotoxins universally with any potential targeting ligand. We have also shown restrictocin to have anti-HIV activity which is dependent on its specific ribonucleolytic activity.
Saporin, another protein toxin extensively studied in my laboratory, belongs to the family of ribosome-inactivating proteins that potently inhibit protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells, by specifically depurinating rRNA, which results in cell death. We have demonstrated that saporin possesses two catalytic activities, namely RNA N-glycosidase and genomic DNA fragmentation activity, and for its complete cytotoxic activity both these activities are absolutely critical. We have further elucidated the mechanism of binding and internalization of saporin in eukaryotic cells. My group has identified crucial determinants for the potent cytotoxic activity of saporin, and also established its mechanism of apoptosis induction and anti-HIV activity.
Caseinolytic proteases (Clps), members of the heat shock protein family, in many pathogenic bacteria have been shown to be involved in their virulence, survival in the host and dormancy. A similar mechanism may be operative in M. tuberculosis also and the members of the Clp protease family will be attractive drug targets. Our current studies are aimed at understanding the functioning of Clp protease machinery in M. tuberculosis by in vitro biochemical characterizations and by inactivating these proteins in vivo . As a first study in this field, our group has characterized M. tuberculosis ClpC1and established the role of N-terminal domain in its function. Also, we are investigating the regulation of heat shock proteins, particularly the role of transcriptional repressors, HspR and HrcA in M. tuberculosis . We have delineated the mechanism of repression by HspR of M. tuberculosis .

We have reconstituted the RNase P of M. tuberculosis in vitro , and delineated the role of a histidine in the RNR motif in its catalysis. Our studies show that the histidine in the RNR motif of M. tuberculosis is able to substitute optimally for asparagine found in the majority of the protein components of other bacterial RNase P enzymes. Further, we have analyzed the residues in RNase P protein of M. tuberculosis that differ from the residues generally conserved in other well-studied bacterial RNase Ps. We have demonstrated that Phe23, Val27 and Ala70 are involved in substrate binding, while Arg72 and Arg93 are involved in interactions with other residues within the protein to provide the protein a conformation conducive for activity.

former_faculty.name: Dr. Asok Mukhopadhyay
former_faculty.research_interest: Hematopoietic stem cells niche and its control Adult stem cell plasticity and epigenetic modifications (Hepatic cells and dopaminergic neurons) Cellular therapy: Parkinson’s disease, liver fibrosis and hemophilia A Hematopoietic cells in progression of cancer Bone tissue engineering
former_faculty.research_summary:
Our laboratory is focused on understanding the dynamic regulation of hematopoiesis, stem cell plasticity, cell-based therapies for genetic and degenerative diseases, and the role of hematopoietic cells in tumor progression and metastasis.

1. Hematopoietic Stem Cell (HSC) Niche and Bone Marrow Regeneration
   We investigate how the bone marrow niche regulates the engraftment and fate of exogenous HSCs. Our findings reveal that during marrow regeneration:

Donor HSCs undergo transient amplification through symmetric divisions.

Donor cells rescue host HSCs from apoptosis and promote proliferation by activating key cell cycle regulators.

This is followed by a return to quiescence, indicating that hematopoiesis is tightly governed by signals from the niche, particularly stromal cells.

Gene expression analyses (cDNA microarray and real-time RT-PCR) have shown that hematopoietic growth factors are robustly expressed during the early stages of regeneration. Several previously uncharacterized genes are also upregulated; their functional roles in hematopoiesis are currently under investigation.

We are also studying HSC aging, with preliminary data suggesting that both intrinsic cellular mechanisms and extrinsic niche-derived factors contribute to age-related hematopoietic decline.

2. Stem Cell Plasticity and Regenerative Medicine
   Addressing the global challenge of donor shortages, our lab explores the plasticity of adult stem cells for application in cell therapy. This includes:

Phenotypic correction in mouse models of Hemophilia A and alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency using bone marrow (BM)-derived stem cells.

Development of BM-based cell therapy for early-stage liver fibrosis.

In our liver regeneration program, we follow two key strategies:

(a) In situ differentiation of BM-derived stem cells into hepatocytes

(b) Generation of induced hepatocytes by overexpressing master regulatory genes in fibroblasts

Using real-time PCR and FISH, we demonstrated that BM-derived cells can engraft and differentiate into hepatocytes and endothelial cells, contributing to functional recovery. Notably, Hemophilia A mice receiving uncommitted BM cell transplants showed long-term expression of active Factor VIII without inhibitor formation.

Current work includes studying the genetic and epigenetic changes accompanying lineage reprogramming in BM-derived hepatic cells.

To overcome immune rejection in transplantation, we have shown that peripheral tolerance can be induced by co-transplantation with allo-reactive Treg cells, particularly effective in liver transplantation.

3. Neuroregeneration Using Mesenchymal Stem Cells
   In a parallel plasticity-focused project, we have shown that mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) derived from fetal liver can differentiate into dopaminergic neuron-like cells. These cells:

Exhibit markers and functions comparable to dopamine-producing neurons

Improve motor behavior in Parkinson’s disease (PD) mouse models upon transplantation

Ongoing studies aim to decipher the molecular mechanisms driving MSC differentiation into functional neurons.

4. Hematopoietic Cells in Tumor Progression and Metastasis
   We are also investigating the role of hematopoietic cells in cancer progression, focusing on ovarian and lung tumor models. Our research has identified:

A specific subtype of hematopoietic lineage cells that frequently fuses with tumor cells

These fused cells exhibit enhanced migratory capacity and increased genetic instability, suggesting functional advantages in tumor dissemination

We hypothesize that cell fusion events contribute to tumor aggressiveness by transferring active hematopoietic factors to the tumor genome.

former_faculty.research_summary:
Our research addresses key challenges in transgenesis, male infertility, and testicular cell biology, integrating advanced genetic, proteomic, and transcriptomic approaches to develop innovative tools, improve reproductive health, and create genetically modified animals for biopharmaceutical applications.

1. Development of a Non-lethal In Vivo Transgenesis Platform
   Traditional transgenic techniques rely on the destruction of numerous fertilized oocytes, making them inefficient and ethically contentious. To overcome these limitations, we pioneered a death-less transgenesis technique involving in vivo electroporation of plasmid DNA into dividing spermatogonial stem cells in the testis. This method enables rapid generation of transgenic offspring without sacrificing females, marking a paradigm shift in animal biotechnology:

Mice (Nature Methods, 2008; Scientific Reports, 2013)

Rats (Molecular Therapy: Nucleic Acids, 2016)

This approach is simple, reproducible, and adaptable across species. Current applications include the generation of transgenic farm animals to produce therapeutic proteins in milk, making them more cost-effective and accessible. To this end, we isolated and validated the buffalo β-casein promoter (Journal of Biotechnology, 2015), enabling tissue-specific expression of therapeutic genes in the mammary gland.

2. Molecular Regulation of Male Fertility and Puberty Onset
   Amidst rising rates of male infertility, our work has sought to elucidate molecular events associated with the onset of male fertility at puberty, focusing on Sertoli cells, the "nurse cells" essential for germ cell support and differentiation.

Key contributions include:

Functional studies using monkey testicular Sertoli cells revealing pubertal molecular signatures (J. Clin. Endocrinol. Metab., 2006)

Insights into androgen and FSH signaling defects affecting Sertoli cell function (Human Reproduction, 2012; Am. J. Physiol., 2012; Endocrinology, 2015)

Identification of molecular cues underlying idiopathic infertility in men, with implications for diagnostic and therapeutic development

3. Multi-Omics and Functional Genomics of Spermatogenesis
   We employ a multi-omics approach to understand the genetic regulation of spermatogenic activation and arrest, integrating data from:

Transcriptomics via microarray analysis and TRANSFAC-guided computational screening

Proteomics using SWATH-MS to identify differentially expressed proteins in active vs. inactive testes

Comparative genomics across mouse, rat, and monkey models

These analyses have led to the discovery of novel genes and regulatory factors, many of which are being functionally validated through transgenic rodent models.

4. Functional Characterization of microRNAs in Spermatogenesis
   To further refine our understanding of gene regulation, we investigated the role of microRNAs in testicular function:

Performed next-generation sequencing of microRNAs from spermatogenically active and inactive testes

Identified numerous differentially expressed miRNAs, some of which may regulate key stages of spermatogenesis

Functional validation is underway using overexpression systems and SPONGE-mediated sequestration in transgenic rodents to delineate the precise role of these miRNAs

Our research integrates cutting-edge molecular techniques with a systems biology perspective, advancing the frontiers of reproductive genetics, non-invasive transgenesis, and biopharmaceutical production in animals.

former_faculty.research_summary:
Our laboratory investigates the immunogenetic basis of differential immune responses in both infectious and autoimmune diseases. Individuals vary significantly in their immune responses to infections—some clear the infection, some develop immunity, while others progress to chronic disease. This variation is influenced by an integrated network of genetic factors involved in antigen presentation, immune regulation, and inflammation.

We focus on genes such as:

Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC)

Low Molecular Weight Proteases (LMP)

Transporters Associated with Antigen Processing (TAP)

Cytotoxic T-Lymphocyte Antigen-4 (CTLA-4)

Cytokine genes

Vitamin D receptor

PTPN22

Phase II detoxification genes (e.g., Glutathione S-transferase, NQO1)

Our research spans diseases such as leprosy, tuberculosis, HCV-HIV co-infections, and autoimmune conditions including psoriasis, hypoparathyroidism, Type 1 Diabetes (T1D), and vitiligo.

1. Type 1 Diabetes: Immunotherapy and Beta Cell Regeneration
   T1D is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the destruction of pancreatic beta cells, resulting in insulin dependence. Current insulin therapy manages symptoms but does not address the root autoimmune cause.

We are developing a dual therapeutic strategy:

Immune modulation: Using nano/micro-particle encapsulated immunomodulatory peptides to attenuate autoreactive T cells and suppress autoimmunity.

Beta cell regeneration: Utilizing mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) from Balb/c mouse bone marrow to restore insulin production.

Key initiatives:

In vivo testing of peptide-loaded biodegradable particles in streptozotocin-induced diabetic Balb/c and Non-Obese Diabetic (NOD) mice

Differentiation of MSCs into insulin-producing cells using multiple protocols

Assessing combined or independent efficacy of stem cell therapy and immune modulation

This approach aims to develop a curative strategy for T1D by targeting both immune dysfunction and beta cell loss.

2. Vitiligo: Autoimmunity, Genetics, and Molecular Pathogenesis
   Vitiligo is the most common pigmentation disorder, affecting 0.5–1% of the global population, caused by the selective destruction of melanocytes.

Our research focuses on:

Immunogenetic predisposition: We conducted the largest study on MHC associations in vitiligo, revealing key differences in peptide-binding residues of MHC class I and II between patients and controls. These differences influence the presentation of autoantigens.

Immune dysregulation: Elevated levels of cytokines were observed in both lesional skin and peripheral blood, contributing to melanocyte loss.

Epigenetic regulation: Genome-wide profiling identified several microRNAs (miRNAs) upregulated in lesional skin versus non-lesional skin of the same patients.

Current work includes:

Functional studies on the impact of identified cytokines and miRNAs on primary melanocyte and keratinocyte cultures

Dissecting the molecular networks driving melanocyte destruction and melanin loss

This comprehensive approach seeks to unravel the complex immunogenetic and epigenetic mechanisms underlying vitiligo and to identify potential therapeutic targets.

former_faculty.research_interest: Effect of carbohydrates on structure and function of glycopeptides
former_faculty.research_summary:
Our laboratory is broadly engaged in understanding the structural and functional implications of protein glycosylation, a ubiquitous post-translational modification known to impact protein folding, stability, intracellular trafficking, and biological activity. While glycosylation can stabilize peptide conformation and restrict dynamic fluctuations, its structural microheterogeneity—resulting from diverse glycosylation patterns—often complicates the functional characterization of glycoproteins.

To address this, we utilize chemically synthesized homogeneous glycopeptides as rational model systems, enabling systematic studies of carbohydrate structures and their local perturbations. Our research focuses on elucidating the differential roles of carbohydrate domains in two key model systems:

1. Antimicrobial Glycopeptides of Innate Immune Origin
   Insects exhibit resistance to bacterial infections through the production of diverse proline-rich antimicrobial peptides such as drosocin, pyrrhocoricin, formaecins, diptericin, and lebocins. A distinctive feature of these peptides is the presence of O-glycosylated threonine residues, essential for their maximal antimicrobial activity. However, the precise functional role of the carbohydrate moiety remains poorly understood.

Our studies aim to:

Investigate the structure–function relationship of these antimicrobial glycopeptides.

Decipher the mechanism of action, hypothesized to involve bacterial cell entry and intracellular target binding.

Identify and characterize bacterial target proteins to further understand the bactericidal mechanism of these cationic glycopeptides.

2. Novel Glycopeptide Inhibitors of Thrombin
   Thrombin is a serine protease pivotal to the regulation of hemostasis, with additional roles in cell cycle regulation, inflammation, pregnancy, and several pathological conditions, including coagulation disorders, cancer, and bloodborne infections. Given its central role, thrombin has long been considered a promising therapeutic target.

Our objective is to develop novel, fast-acting, specific, and potent glycopeptide inhibitors of thrombin. To this end:

We design and synthesize customized glycopeptide inhibitors.

Conduct structure–function studies to optimize their activity and specificity.

Explore the potential of these inhibitors in addressing thrombin-associated pathologies.

By integrating synthetic chemistry, structural biology, and functional immunology, our research seeks to provide mechanistic insights into glycopeptide function and develop novel therapeutic candidates targeting both infectious diseases and thrombin-mediated disorders.

former_faculty.research_summary:
Summary of Research
We engaged in the development and evaluation of novel immunotherapeutic and chemo-immunotherapeutic strategies against tuberculosis and cancer, with a special focus on the immunomodulatory potential of Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP).

1. Protective Efficacy of MIP in Tuberculosis
   M. indicus pranii (MIP), a non-pathogenic mycobacterial strain sharing cross-reactive antigens with M. tuberculosis, is being investigated as an alternative vaccine candidate to M. bovis BCG. Earlier studies demonstrated that killed MIP can confer protection against M. tuberculosis infection.

Our current research focuses on:

Evaluating the protective efficacy of MIP in both live and killed forms

Comparing parenteral and aerosol routes of immunization

Assessing immune responses elicited by MIP and comparing them to those generated by BCG vaccination

Utilizing various animal models of tuberculosis, including mice and guinea pigs

We also explore MIP as an adjunct to standard chemotherapy, aiming to enhance therapeutic efficacy and reduce treatment duration in both sub-acute and chronic stages of tuberculosis.

2. Immunotherapy and Chemo-immunotherapy in Cancer
   The role of the immune system in cancer control is well established. However, tumors often develop mechanisms to suppress host immunity within the local microenvironment. Our goal is to reactivate anti-tumor immunity using immunomodulators such as MIP and to combine them with standard chemotherapy to achieve a synergistic effect.

MIP as an Immunotherapeutic Agent
Building on our findings in tuberculosis, where MIP induces strong Th1-type immune responses, we investigated MIP’s anti-tumor activity in murine tumor models. Studies include:

Evaluating MIP as a standalone immunomodulatory agent

Assessing MIP in combination with commercial chemotherapeutic agents

Investigating mechanisms of MIP-mediated immune activation, including Th1 polarization and macrophage stimulation

Development of Chemo-immunotherapeutic Formulations
We designed novel formulations that combine the cytotoxic effects of chemotherapy with the immune-activating potential of immunostimulants. Our strategy includes:

Conjugating Paclitaxel (PTX) with SP-LPS, a non-toxic derivative of LPS, to create a dual-function molecule

Formulating nanoparticles co-encapsulating PTX and SP-LPS

Evaluating their anticancer activity in preclinical models

Future directions involve:

Exploring alternative polymers with macrophage-stimulating and anti-tumor properties

Optimizing formulation parameters for enhanced tumor microenvironment modulation and immune priming

Through these integrated efforts, we aim to develop innovative vaccine and immunotherapy platforms that not only enhance host immunity against tuberculosis and cancer but also improve therapeutic outcomes through synergistic chemo-immunotherapy.

former_faculty.name: Dr. Chandrima Shaha
former_faculty.research_interest: Cell death is one of the fundamental biological processes required to maintain normal development. A cell’s decision to live or die is tightly regulated by signals originating from various sources. Our interest is to elucidate the regulatory processes of cell death and the associated mechanisms.
former_faculty.research_summary: The course of evolution has shaped different species for their survival during conditions of stress, natural development, differentiation and growth. These conditions represent the two faces of the same coin because continued growth or continuous stress would hamper survival. To circumvent these problems, all animal cells have evolved the capability to kill themselves by turning on gene-encoded cell suicide programs. These programs not only help the organisms to survive in conditions of excessive stress but also help prevent abnormal growth. The decision of whether a particular cell will live or die is tightly regulated by many different signals originating both from within the cell and from its environment. The implementation of this self-destruction program leads to a morphologically distinct form of cell death termed apoptosis and deregulation of apoptosis is associated with a variety of diseases including cancer, autoimmune diseases and neurodegenerative disorders. There are considerable variations in which apoptosis occur in different systems and under different conditions. Cell death also occurs via processes such as programmed necrosis and autophagy and it is the balance between survival and these death processes that determines the fate of a cell. The major focus of the laboratory is to elucidate the precise mechanisms of cell death and how this process is regulated by the diverse signalling pathways using unicellular ( Leishmania parasite) and multicellular (cancer cells) model systems with or without genetic manipulations. The aim is to provide a deeper understanding of cell death events that can help in the development of improved therapeutics for diseases associated with anomalous cell death.
